2 Genetic Constitution of A Population 2.1 Frequencies of genes(alleles) and genotypes Genotype frequencies: the freuqncy of a particular genotype being its proportion or percentage among the individuals. Population: in the genetic sense, a population is not just a group of individuals, but a breeding group; and the genetics of a population is concerned not only with the genetic constitution of the individuals but also with the transmission of the genes from one generation to the next. The genetic constitution of a population, refering to the genes it carries, is described by the array of gene(alleles) frequencies; that is, by specification of the alleles present at every locus and the numbers or proportions of the different alleles at each locus. These properties of a population are derived from a theorem, or principle, known as the Hardy-Weinberg law after Hardy and Weinberg, who independently demonstrated them in 1908. A population with constant gene and genotype frequencies is said to be in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. So 2/3 (4 out of 6) sex-linked alleles are carried by females and 1/3 by males in the population.
